turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: I don't think that they have shown either the materiality or the reasonableness, Your Honor.
Now, one thing that is to be noted with respect to that motion is that they ask for the evidence that the state is going to introduce.
The hair wasn't even introduced as very technically interpreted.
The motion does not even apply to the hair.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I understand that, but it does apply to this part of the case involving the shorts.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, it does.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And how at this particular time would the defense have known what the prosecution was going to introduce by way of physical evidence?

turn.speaker: maurice_rosenfield
turn.label: Mr. Maurice Rosenfield
turn.text: I assume that they -- the only way I can answer that question Your Honor is that they were given the right to view all the physical evidence in the case.
He made that motion.
They were allowed to go in.
They were allowed to view all the physical evidence in the case.
Now, they could've based -- the hair was seen of record that they saw the hairs when they made that view.
A motion -- in addition of the fact, that the defense knew that the hair was found in the vagina of the victim, knew that hair of petitioner was taken for comparison purposes.
I do not submit that it is too great a burden on the prosecution -- on the defense.
I beg your pardon, to make a motion for their result of that examination.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Did you say Mr. Michael that among the things they did see was the actual hair taken from the shorts?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: The testimony, Your Honors, states that amongst the physical evidence seen was hair and hairs.
It does not define determining further, yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That would identify them as including that the hair was --

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, hair was in the vial, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: The testimony does not state how it was, Your Honor.
All it states is that “What evidence did you see when you examined it?”
“I saw hairs.”
He stated it, he didn't state whether it was in vial or how it was.
I assumed it was in the vial because that at least was the way it went to the chemist.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was the time they saw that after they made this motion?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: First they --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: After they made motion on page 2, was that when they saw the physical --?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: As I read the record Your Honor, first they were allowed to view the evidence personally.
Then they made the motion --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: When?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: They made the motion to view the evidence as I read it prior to the motion to make the scientific examination of the evidence.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And were allowed to look at it?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: They were, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And then they made the motion for the (Voice Overlap).

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And that was the one that was denied?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Was the original motion granted is that it for defense?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: I am not aware, Your Honor, whether it was just granted by the prosecution or whether there was a court order on that.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did the Court make -- state any reason as to why it was denying him a right to examine?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: The Court does not.
The -- in the Court the state's attorney was asked why he opposed that motion, and he testified Your Honor that he opposed it because they -- he could not be assured.
He was not assured that the evidence would not be -- the chain of evidence would not be some way destroyed by the tests that were going to be taken.
That is why he opposed it, the reason -- the ruling of the judge, however, is not in the record.
The reason or the ruling of the judge is not in the record, Your Honor.
We turn then Your Honors to the question of the bloody shorts.
Now, the chemist for the state literally testified at the trial -- testified at the trial that the shorts did contain blood.
And the state's attorney also testified -- stated in argument referred to these shorts as bloody shorts.
Now, at the District Court in the habeas corpus proceeding --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: May I ask before you get to the District Court.
If the prosecuting attorney describe the blood that was on them or the amount of it, or did he make any representation as to whether this is blood on the shorts?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: I do not think the record indicated that he pointed to any spot, Your Honor.
It said this is blood.
He referred to the document in general as the bloody shorts.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, there are more than spots on that.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: It's covered with something which they now say is paint.
And I wonder if was that represented to the jury in any way as being the blood stained shorts without distinguishing --

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: No statement was made to the jury Your Honor, as far as I know that there was any paint on these.
There was then therefore, the jury would, I assume allow to draw the inference that all the spots were those of blood.
On the other hand, I do not think any direct statement was made any given spot or all spots were blood.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: When did the question first come up about the paint?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: As far as I know Your Honor, in the District Court they did make a scientific examination of all the evidence.
One Martin, a chemist employed by the petitioner here, took 12 strands at out of the more heavily stained areas of that garment, 12 fibers.
He examined those 12 fibers, each out of one of the heavily stained areas.
His testimony was that ten of the fibers contained paint.
One of the fibers are kind of a carbon substance and one of the fibers an unidentified substance.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Mr. Michael, when the shorts were introduced at the trial, did the defense make a motion at that time that they be permitted to have a scientific examination of it?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: As far as I know Your Honor, and I think this is correct, the only motion from the scientific examination was the one that we have referred to with respect to --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Alright, now try to get at the theory of this case.
Suppose at the trial, the state offers the shorts and testimony is to be offered or is being or has been offered to the effect that those are blood stains.
The defense then moves in an appropriate way to be given the opportunity to have a scientific examination of the shorts.
In Illinois law, what would happen?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Generally speaking, I would submit that it would be granted, Your Honor.

The general rule under Illinois law is that, it was enunciated by the Court by the way in reviewing this case, is that there is a qualified -- red-light lining to the discretion of the Court to allow the defense to make scientific evidence of the --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I suppose the trial judge said in all this, “No, I won't let you do that.”
Would that be an error under Illinois law?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: If there were no further basis than that Your Honor, I submit that yes it would be.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I thought you said there was discretion on it?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: It could be reviewed however for abuse of discretion.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: You think it would be introduced as discretion?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: I would if there were no reason at all for denying a motion to make scientific evidence, I would submit that it would be in abuse of discretion.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Why, because it's a denial of fair trial?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well why, that's constitutional principle too, isn't it?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: To the extent that Brady versus Maryland so enunciates it, yes sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did -- may I ask this, did the report of the state's experts who examined these shorts report that the major portion of what's on there is paint?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: The report of the state's expert on that Your Honor was that he had examined it, he had found paint and he made no -- I take it back, he had found blood and he made no test for any other substance.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And he made no reference in his report that the -- that what is so observable there is paint and not blood?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: The chemist did not, Your Honor.
The state's attorney in the District Court did testify that he knew that all of the stains on it were not blood.
That is all we have in the record on that issue.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: He knew that at the time that the shorts was introduced in evidence?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: He so testified in the District Court, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But he didn't disclose that time?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: He did not, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You know whether in summation he used the garment in his summation to the jury?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: He certainly referred to the bloody shots.
Of course, the report of the short hand report, it would not indicate whether he was waiving it or --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But at the time he made reference to it.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: He did, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: He knew that there was -- that at least all of the spots were not blood but some or something else.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And said nothing about it.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Where does that -- I want to be sure he's sure what he did admit it to his knowledge at the time of -- at the clemency hearing or at the habeas corpus hearing --

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: At the habeas corpus --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- he admitted as to his knowledge at the time of the trial that some of the stains, that at least some of the stains were not blood.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Volume 2, Your Honor, page 581.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Volume 2, page 581.
Well, this -- is this the prosecuting attorney at the trial who's testifying?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes, I beg to change that to make it 580, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: This is Blaine Ramsey?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: This is Blaine Ramsey, yes Your Honor, at the bottom of the page.
“Let me ask you this Mr. Ramsey.
As a matter of fact Mr. Ramsey didn't you know at the time of the trial Lloyd Eldon Miller Jr., that these spots in this examination were not blood?”
“Oh!
I knew that all of them were not blood, yes sir.”

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's what you were referring to the --

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes, I was.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Then he said also, “With regard to those that can be seen by the naked eye, you knew at the time of trial, didn't you, that those spots that could be seen by the naked eye were not blood spots.
You knew that, didn't you?”
“Well not conclusively.
I had knowledge from a chemist that there was blood on it.”

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I see that's his further testimony.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Michaels, who was Mr. Litterly?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: He was a chemist, Your Honor, employed by the state bureau of -- I don't really -- criminal -- the scientific arm of the state government at that time.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What about the statement on his testimony at 581.
“Now as to those spots which you knew were not blood, what did you know those to be?
What did you know of those Mr. Ramsey?”
“I'm trying to recollect that.
They said there was also paint on that I think that is remembered only.”
“Who said it was paint?”
“I presume Mr. Litterly but I really do not recall.”

Is that -- are we to get -- take from this that he's suggesting that at the time it was offered at trial, he knew more of then that there were some spots were not blood, he knew that there were spots that were paint, is that it?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: He testified there Your Honor that he knew that some of those spots were paint, I would assume.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But Litterly testified at the trial that he didn't make test on the non-blood.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Right, Your Honor.
He testified only that he had examined for blood and he had made no other tests on the garment.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But in order to -- he tested for blood but he didn't find blood in some of those spots.
At least that is a fair reading of his testimony.
He knew that some of the stains were not blood, so he did test the stains for blood.
And if the prosecuting attorney knew at the time that some of the stains were not blood, the only source of information could be from Mr. Litterly, I presume.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes, I would assume that that would be correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And his source of information would I assume be a written report?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: The written report from Litterly is in the record, and at my recollection of it, it is in the echo -- the report of the exhibits.
The report of Litterly is found at --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: This is not the trial, isn't it?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: No this is the exhibits from the habeas corpus proceeding, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Habeas corpus.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: I think it's number six, Your Honor I'm looking at it now to verify it.
Yes, it is petitioner's exhibit number six.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: This is what the prosecuting attorney knew?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Where -- which one of these items applies to the --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The reproduction is not very good.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: No, it isn't Your Honor.
I'm trying to Your Honor, I'm -- do you have one of your first?
Yes, that's much better.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I see some --

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: It's -- at the next to last page, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Can you read it?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes I can from the original or much better copy of the report than you have available.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The pair of white jockey shorts?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Described as number 17?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Were examined by chemical means and found to be heavily stained with blood.
Further serological examination include the blood was of human origin.
It was probably of group A.
Numerous hairs and fibers were herein to the shorts and were mounted in microscopic examination, a comparison of those hairs of pubic hairs 10 to 15 millimeters.
Some similar characteristics, no definite opinions of whether or not the common origin is possible.
One of the fibers found in the shorts was mounted and compared microscopically, samples of the fibers of the inner pant lining the color, size, etcetera.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: No mention of paint at all.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: No mention of paint, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Oh, what page is that on do you say?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: These are not numbered, Your Honor.
This is exhibit number six, the next to the last page, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, this -- there's no mention here that some of the stains were not blood.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: No there is not, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, then where did the prosecuting attorney get his information that some of the stains were not blood?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: I do not know, Your Honor.
All I know is that in the District Court he --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, how about Mr. Litterly's testimony?
He did testify that some of the stains were --

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes.
He testified that he -- he did not testify that some of the stains were not.
He testified that he knew that some of the stains were not blood.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, how about the testimony at the trial?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Litterly's testimony at the trial you're referring to now, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Did he then say -- he didn't make any mention at all as to other stains, did he, in his testimony?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
Litterly's testimony at the trial appears in the brown colored Volume 4 at page 168.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Okay, thank you very much.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: It stated, “I examined and tested People's Exhibit 3 to determine the nature of the staining material thereon.
That result of the first test was that this material upon the shorts is blood.
I made a second examination it's as close as the blood of human origin and made a further examination which disclosed that the blood was of group A.”
That was his testimony at that time.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, now that -- he made more -- testify?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: More fully did he, on the habeas corpus?
Where was it that he finally conceded that some of the --

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: I'm not sure that he ever did.
It was the state's attorney who conceded that he knew that some of the stains were not blood, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That's the thing I referred to in form of my question.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes.
Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: We submit that on this issue, Your Honors, the critical point is whether there was blood on these shorts.
The petitioner testified that he --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, don't you think under a case like Napue against Illinois, the critical point is, even if there was blood on those shorts, a misrepresentation that the stains you could see there was blood when they knew it was -- if they knew it was paint.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: If there --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Isn't that the knowing use of concept of misrepresentation by the prosecution in a criminal case?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: If there is blood on these shorts, Your Honor, and the mere testimony by the prosecution only is that there are -- is blood in these shorts.
And if they do refer to them as bloody shorts, if there is blood on them, I submit that even though there's also paint, there is no going beyond the truth, if you will, as indicated by Napue.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, as I understand it, today you can't find any blood on it?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: On what's in there.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: However, the chemist for the prosecution did testify that he had no opinion today as to whether there was any blood on it or not.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Today the appearance of those and the --

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Except for one stain, Your Honor that is unidentifiable in origin.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Mr. Michaels as you held those up, I don't -- it hardly seems an unspotted -- look at that.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: It --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: If the blood has now disappeared, there's certainly an awful lot of paint.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes there is, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Suppose the prosecutor had expressly represented to the jury that all of those spots were blood, would that have been your judgment, would that have been error under Illinois law?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: I would think not only under Illinois but under the decision of this Court it would have been, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: That's because it would've not been consummate with our ideas of a fair trial.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: So that what we have here is the variation in the sense that there was represented but there was blood on the shorts with no particularization of the exhibit, which was physically before the jury.
It was not all blood but mostly paint as to the appearance to the naked eye now.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes sir.
However, I do want to go back to the point I was making with respect to Mr. Justice Stewart's question.
The petitioner did testify in his confession, admitted in his confession that these were his shorts.
The critical issue --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Incidentally, where does this confession appear here, anywhere I can't --

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes, it is in the record, Your Honor on before -- it appears really in two places.
One, Mr. Christensen who took the confession, testified as to what he said to him during the interrogation and then another time that Mr. Baudino read his confession into the record.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Where are the two places?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Mr. Christensen's statement begins on 128, I believe it is, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That would be of Volume 1?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: This would be the trial transcript, Your Honor, the brown covered by --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Volume 4.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Volume 4.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Sorry to take your time but I haven't --

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: No, no.
Then you have the -- we are looking now, Your Honor, for the -- where the confession.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Right, thank you very much.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was there any evidence in the record of about how that paint got on those shorts?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: No, there's nothing at all, Your Honor, as far as I know.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What was this man's occupation?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Would you excuse me?
The confession Your Honor of the defendant was right under the record of page 144.
Pardon me, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I asked, what was his occupation?
As I recall it was evidence of him being a taxi driver.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes there was, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: He was not a painter.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: No, he was not, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I understood there was some evidence in one of the proceedings to the effect that these shorts did not fit the defendant.
Is there anything from the prosecution to rebut that?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: The testimony was, Your Honor, that the -- they would've been tight and uncomfortable if he had worn them.
There's nothing to rebut that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Was there any rebuttal of that?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: No, there was not, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Anything to show that the confirmation of the man had changed in the years that he was either fatter or thinner at the time this testimony was taken and at the time of the crime?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: No, there was not, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Perhaps I misunderstood.
I thought you were starting to tell us at the time that I interrupted you to ask you where in the record the confession appeared.
I thought you were trying to starting to tell us that in his confession, he admitted that those shorts were his?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes, he did Your Honor, in his confession.
He later denied it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But he never made any confession.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes, but in his confession he admitted that the shorts were his.
And so I submit that the relevant question is whether they did contain blood.
If they did contain blood, this was the critical point.
The presence of paint in addition to the blood, I respectfully submit, was immaterial.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where did they get the shorts, from him?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: They found -- a policeman found them in a old abandoned apartment building which was referred to at that time as the Van Buren Flats.

In his confession, he stated that he had discarded them in the Van Buren Flats, but if I remember the testimony correctly, the police had found it before his confession if I'm not mistaken on that point.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I'm sorry must have read them -- perhaps I read it too quickly.
This is the confession at page 145?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: 147, can you refer me to the admission that these particular shorts were his?
I see that there is -- he states that he removed the shorts, but I don't find any --

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Perhaps it was in the statement of Mr. Christensen sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: If you don't find it there.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I don't find it in the confession.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I found -- I find on a page 130 that he said he did this -- discard his shorts at Van Buren Flats, but that doesn't -- that's not the same as saying that those shorts are his.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: I agree with that, Your Honor.
My recollection from the record is that he was shown the flats and he stated that they were -- I maybe in error on that.
It was my recollection from reading the record, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well he agreed that -- he conceded that they had been left at this place and they found these at that place.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's probably might be accountable for your error.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: That is --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I find what you're referring to now, on page 132 just below the center of the page.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Michael, I gather the impression from reading the phrase that the state in introducing the confession and the presentation of its case told the jury or left the impression with the jury that he have had obtained the confession of the defendant and then had verified it through these things and that they had found these things as a result of the confession.
And I gather the impression also that there had been evidence later produced to show that they had these things before the confession and verify them by this confession.
Now, did the state deny the latter?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: As I remember that point, Your Honor, it's my understanding that the reading of the record that the items were found before the confession.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Was that at any time represented to the jury that these things were found afterwards as a result of that confession?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: The petitioner has claimed that they are, Your Honor.
As I read that section that he referred to, I was not -- I thought it was ambiguous which way they were referring to it.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Would you have that citation recorded?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Don't you think that's -- that might be important?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: If there were knowing misrepresentation to closing argument, I would say it would be very significant, Your Honor.

If there was no evidence, however, brought out that he deliberately misstated anything, it is possible that a mistake could occur in -- by prosecution in closing argument which would not be deliberate mistake and would not amount to constitutional proportions.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But neither that an important thing, it seems to me, whether these things were found and developed as a result of the plain confession that he made or whether they had these things and before the confession and did not report it to the --

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: The argument that you are referring to, Your Honor, is on page 375 of the volume printed by this Court, Volume 4, Your Honor.
And it relates to the jacket of my -- attorney for the petitioner in form where he relates --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Where is that, the upper part of the volume?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: About the middle of the page I believe, Your Honor.
They could not have known, but when they put it there to find, the jacket was found where he had said he had put it.
Words are about the middle of the page, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: I beg your -- 375, I beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That's the one they could not have known, but when they went there to find the jacket it was found --

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- where he said he put it.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
We turn then Your Honors --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, did -- is -- which is true, that they did find this thing after the confession or before?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: My understanding of the record is that they found it before the confession, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And that this, while it might not have been with intention to deceive, but was, untrue?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: If that is -- as I read that, Your Honor, I am not absolutely clear just what the meaning of it.
If you interpret that as saying that we took his -- what he told us and went out and there we found it then it would be untrue, yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: We turn then to the question of the advice to Mrs. Baxter that she had a right not to talk to the defense in this case.
Now, Mrs. Baxter testified at the pardon and parole proceedings that she had been receiving many calls and was being bothered by the defense attorney and she was, in her words, perturbed.
She called up the state's attorney and asked what the situation was.
He told her in effect that, “You have a right not to talk to the defense if you want to.”

This is corroborated by his own testimony at the District Court where he testified that he told other witnesses amongst her that by request that they had a right not to talk to the defense and they must make up their own mind whether they wanted to or not.
Now, we submit that this statement is absolutely correct.
Absent a subpoena to some particular hearing, every private individual has a right not only to talk not to the defense, but not to talk to the prosecution, absent an appropriate subpoena.
We submit that there was absolutely no violation of any rights in respect to that statement.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I was wondering about her testimony when it was offered and when the Court was asked for permission to permit her testimony as a court witness.
The prosecution said they would consent to it only if her unreliability was conceded.
Now, why would that -- is that a normal thing?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Let me correct that statement.
Just -- my understanding, Your Honor is with that the Court said that rather than the prosecution.
The Court said, “If you will state to me that she is unreliable in some way, I will allow you to call her as a court's witness.
If you do not so state then I will give you great latitude in asking leading questions and various examinations you want, but I will not call her as a court witness.”
They then refused that offer -- they refused the Court's offer to have called her and have this great leeway in question -- with respect to leading questions.
I assume they testified because they did not want to be bound by the testimony of someone whom they did not know who was going to testify.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is that a test of whether a person -- the defendant should be entitled to call a witness as the Court's witness that he must admit that there's some unreliability?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: I think it is -- the question is pretty much within the discretion of the Court, Your Honor.
And I don't think it's subject to review for abuse in the same way as the scientific evidence was as I referred earlier to the question of Mr. Justice Fortas.
I think that if the Court -- if you can show some reason to the Court why he should be called as the Court's witness, that he pretty well usually is.
The Court, in exercise of its discretion in this case, merely believed that they had not shown sufficient grounds to exercise his discretion in that regard.
We turn then to the question of the unreliable witness, Betty Baldwin, not Betty Baldwin-Curry.
The prosecution -- the petitioner in this case contends that the prosecution was in error for calling that witness when they knew that she was unreliable.

We submit, Your Honors, that there is absolutely no constitutional requirement that prohibits the calling of a witness, who in the past has not been believed if, and this is the big if, they do believe her testimony on this occasion.
Now, on this occasion, the evidence is rather complete that at least two people so testified that they fully believed her on this occasion.
On that basis, they called her and we believe that it is a proper to call a witness whose testimony you believe even though at some past occasion you may not have believed this witness' testimony.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Which one would they believe?
Which part of her testimony would they believe, for in the Court, she said she had known him for two years and prior to that time she had told the police that she knew him for five weeks?

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Well, there is another factor in that regard, Your Honor.
When -- if the she had told the police that she knew him at the time of the crime for five weeks.
Now, this question was asked at the trial which was ten months after the crime.
How long have you known him, not how long had you known him Your Honor, not how long had you known him at the time of the crime, but how long have you known him, which means from the present past.
And I submit, Your Honor, that the correct answer to that would have been 11 months, because she had known him at the time that question was asked for 11 months.
Now, I submit Your Honor, that to allow that to go unrefuted is absolutely immaterial.
There is no materiality at all in this record to the significance of whether that she had known him 11 months or two years.
The defendant states there is some materiality --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Do you have the citation to that, but don't take the time to look.
If you don't know, don't bother.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: You mean as to the -- where as to the formal questioned asked?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: As to whether they said, “How long have you known him?”

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Yes I have it right here, Your Honor, it's in Volume 2, -- Volume 2 page 702 at the top of the page.
At the very top of the page, Your Honor, it refers “Do you know the defendant Lloyd Eldon Miller?”
She said, “Yes sir.”
“How long have you known him?”
“Approximately two years.”

The principle -- there is concluding that thought Your Honor also if there's a contention under Napue versus Illinois that they allowed knowing testimony to go in the record as they did not contradict that statement.
There is absolutely no evidence in this record that they were aware of the statement was made.

Now, there was the fact that that statement had been made to the prosecution, but there was no evidence that they had gone down that statement and checked every one of her answers against them, I'm sure they knew it in substance.

But this was such a, I submit, immaterial point that they probably didn't even realize that she was violating the statement that they had given, or at least there's no evidence in the record that they had, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Michael, may I ask you concerning this witness if it is the fact that they have concluded before this proceeding that this witness had made a false accusation against another person for a crime that she said he had confessed to her but was not true.

And then also that she had made another one which was under investigation and which the experts found that it was inconclusive but they believed that she was not telling the truth and that the county authorities who prosecuted this case suggested that they discontinue the investigation of the truth of that statement until this case was tried so she could be a witness here.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: Your Honor, what you say is very -- is in substance.
Now, I know of only one prior occasion that she had made a story about another crime that was this narcotics story.
With respect to that statement, she was given a lie detector test to check whether it was right.
The result was inconclusive.
They said that they found -- they did not believe her, although the test was inconclusive and that they were going to drop the matter.
The only other instance that I can think of which talks to their -- to the unreliability relates to the statement that Mr. Malmgren, the attorney for the petitioner had tried to coerce this witness.
Now, as far as I read the record in this case, those claims have never been disproving, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I understood that there was an investigation of that, and the authorities indicated that they thought that was not true, but the people who prosecuted this case suggested that the investigation be discontinued until after the trial of this case.

turn.speaker: richard_a_michael
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Michael
turn.text: That was -- the statement that they believe was not true of hers related to the narcotics story, Your Honor.
There was no evidence one way or another whether they believed the story with respect to the Attorney Malmgren.

However, they did -- the statement -- the prosecution did say, “Let's not get that question out of this case so there'll be no question of prejudice,” you know, to the defendant by the fact that his attorney made the some question of improper statements to a prosecution witness.
So that was how it all advanced and was either the last statement in the record on that Your Honor is that it either still pending or is been dismissed.
I assume it has been dismissed, but there has never been a hearing on it.
It has never been proved conclusively one way or another whether that allegation was correct or not.
Thank you, Your Honors.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Lassers.

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
I believe that everything that we desire to say has been said, unless the Court has questions, I have nothing further.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Very well.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Can I ask you one last question?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Certainly.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: In your petition for habeas corpus in the District Court, did you rely on the ground of coerced confession?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
My recollection is that we did.
Yes, we did rely on that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, did the District Court rule on it or not?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: He ruled that it was not coerced, Mr. Justice White.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Did the Court of Appeals rule?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: I think they did.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But at least you -- this is not the first time you've raised the issue of coerced confession in this Court, isn't it?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: In this Court?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You've raised it below, on the preserved two points of the --

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Oh, yes!

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Very well.

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Thank you.
